prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC3169: low resolution CO(2-1) imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Low resolution (0.5") CO imaging of SMBH mass measurement candidates.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our targets typically have integrated CO line widths of a few 100 km/s, but although at any given position the line is much narrower (few km/s), we need not resolve the lines spectrally. A broad baseband with moderate spectra resolution is thus sufficient for our line observations, and the 1875 MHz (roughly 2450 km/s) baseband with 976 kHz (roughly 1.3 km/s) channels is ideal. We will likely bin our data to 10 km/s binned channels, but will adjust the binning depending on the exact brightness of the line, to reach the best compromise between velocity resolution and S/N (see Davis 2014 for a discussion of the figure of merit for SMBH mass measurements).
The CO(2-1) line is our primary target. As no other accessible line (all systematically much fainter) is likely to be detected with any significant S/N, we position the other 3 ALMA basebands to try to detect and quantify any continuum. The ability to accurately subtract the continuum (when present) from the line is crucial, especially at low S/N. Continuum detections would also allow to quantify the amount of dust present in our targets in a spatially-resolved way.

The requested moderate resolution imaging aims to characterise the central (0.5"-1" or typically 50-100 pc) molecular gas distribution and kinematics of potential targets for future higher resolution (0.1" or typically 10 pc) imaging and SMBH mass measurement. At this exploratory stage the exact synthesised beam is somewhat flexible, but a 1" beam would yield a total time outrageously dominated by overheads (typically 2 min on source, 21 minute overheads), while a beam smaller than 0.5" is unnecessary at this point.
As we are only interested here in the central molecular gas distribution and kinematics, we are not interested in structures that may extend beyond the maximum resolvable scale of the array used. We have thus set the largest angular scales such as to avoid the need for multiple (smaller) array configurations. In any case, molecular gas usually breaks down into small structures (molecular clouds) at high angular resolution (studies of nearby galaxies reveal that at most 50% of the CO flux is diffuse). We therefore fully expect to map stuctures smaller than the maximum resolvable scale well beyond that radius and throughout the primary beam.

For the follow-up SMBH mass measurements, we must resolve the Keplerian rise of the circular velocity curves at the smallest spatial scales, thus requiring high angular resolution ALMA observations (0.1" or 10 pc), and therefore objects with high CO surface brightnesses. Galaxy molecular gas surface densities are typically 100-400 M_sun pc^-2, so for the current moderate resolution imaging we aim to reach a surface density of 100 M_sun pc^-2 with S/N = 5 (indeed only slightly deeper than the surface densities reached by our current proposals for actual SMBH mass measurements). Assuming a standard CO conversion factor alpha_CO = 4.3 M_sun (K km/s)^-1 pc^-2, a CO(2-1)/CO(1-0) ratio of 1, a channel width of 10 km/s (see below), and a synthesised beam of 0.5" (see below), this results in a required sensitivity of 1.25 mJy beam^-1 per channel at CO(2-1). According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this require a total time of typically 33 min (10 min on source, 23 min of overheads including calibrations).
The CO(2-1) line is our primary target. As no other accessible line (all systematically much fainter) is likely to be detected with any significant S/N, we position the other 3 ALMA basebands to try to detect and quantify any continuum. The ability to accurately subtract the continuum (when present) from the line is crucial, especially at low S/N. Continuum detections would also allow to quantify the amount of dust present in our targets in a spatially-resolved

As we are only interested here in the central molecular gas distribution and kinematics, we are not interested in structures that may extend beyond the maximum resolvable scale of the array used. We have thus set the largest angular scales such as to avoid the need for multiple (smaller) array configurations. In any case, molecular gas usually breaks down into small structures (molecular clouds) at high angular resolution (studies of nearby galaxies reveal that at most 50% of the CO flux is diffuse). We therefore fully expect to map stuctures smaller than the maximum resolvable scale well beyond that radius and throughout the primary beam.

For the follow-up SMBH mass measurements, we must resolve the Keplerian rise of the circular velocity curves at the smallest spatial scales, thus requiring high angular resolution ALMA observations (0.1" or 10 pc), and therefore objects with high CO surface brightnesses. Galaxy molecular gas surface densities are typically 100-400 M_sun pc^-2, so for the current moderate resolution imaging we aim to reach a surface density of 100 M_sun pc^-2 with S/N = 5 (indeed only slightly deeper than the surface densities reached by our current proposals for actual SMBH mass measurements). Assuming a standard CO conversion factor alpha_CO = 4.3 M_sun (K km/s)^-1 pc^-2, a CO(2-1)/CO(1-0) ratio of 1, a channel width of 10 km/s (see below), and a synthesised beam of 0.5" (see below), this results in a required sensitivity of 1.25 mJy beam^-1 per channel at CO(2-1). According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this require a total time of typically 33 min (10 min on source, 23 min of overheads including calibrations).
The CO(2-1) line is our primary target. As no other accessible line (all systematically much fainter) is likely to be detected with any significant S/N, we position the other 3 ALMA basebands to try to detect and quantify any continuum. The ability to accurately subtract the continuum (when present) from the line is crucial, especially at low S/N. Continuum detections would also allow to quantify the amount of dust present in our targets in a spatially-resolved

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PGC043387: low resolution CO(2-1) imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Low resolution (0.5") CO imaging of SMBH mass measurement candidates.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our targets typically have integrated CO line widths of a few 100 km/s, but although at any given position the line is much narrower (few km/s), we need not resolve the lines spectrally. A broad baseband with moderate spectra resolution is thus sufficient for our line observations, and the 1875 MHz (roughly 2450 km/s) baseband with 976 kHz (roughly 1.3 km/s) channels is ideal. We will likely bin our data to 10 km/s binned channels, but will adjust the binning depending on the exact brightness of the line, to reach the best compromise between velocity resolution and S/N (see Davis 2014 for a discussion of the figure of merit for SMBH mass measurements).
The CO(2-1) line is our primary target. As no other accessible line (all systematically much fainter) is likely to be detected with any significant S/N, we position the other 3 ALMA basebands to try to detect and quantify any continuum. The ability to accurately subtract the continuum (when present) from the line is crucial, especially at low S/N. Continuum detections would also allow to quantify the amount of dust present in our targets in a spatially-resolved way.

The requested moderate resolution imaging aims to characterise the central (0.5"-1" or typically 50-100 pc) molecular gas distribution and kinematics of potential targets for future higher resolution (0.1" or typically 10 pc) imaging and SMBH mass measurement. At this exploratory stage the exact synthesised beam is somewhat flexible, but a 1" beam would yield a total time outrageously dominated by overheads (typically 2 min on source, 21 minute overheads), while a beam smaller than 0.5" is unnecessary at this point.
As we are only interested here in the central molecular gas distribution and kinematics, we are not interested in structures that may extend beyond the maximum resolvable scale of the array used. We have thus set the largest angular scales such as to avoid the need for multiple (smaller) array configurations. In any case, molecular gas usually breaks down into small structures (molecular clouds) at high angular resolution (studies of nearby galaxies reveal that at most 50% of the CO flux is diffuse). We therefore fully expect to map stuctures smaller than the maximum resolvable scale well beyond that radius and throughout the primary beam.

For the follow-up SMBH mass measurements, we must resolve the Keplerian rise of the circular velocity curves at the smallest spatial scales, thus requiring high angular resolution ALMA observations (0.1" or 10 pc), and therefore objects with high CO surface brightnesses. Galaxy molecular gas surface densities are typically 100-400 M_sun pc^-2, so for the current moderate resolution imaging we aim to reach a surface density of 100 M_sun pc^-2 with S/N = 5 (indeed only slightly deeper than the surface densities reached by our current proposals for actual SMBH mass measurements). Assuming a standard CO conversion factor alpha_CO = 4.3 M_sun (K km/s)^-1 pc^-2, a CO(2-1)/CO(1-0) ratio of 1, a channel width of 10 km/s (see below), and a synthesised beam of 0.5" (see below), this results in a required sensitivity of 1.25 mJy beam^-1 per channel at CO(2-1). According to the ALMA sensitivity calculator, this require a total time of typically 33 min (10 min on source, 23 min of overheads including calibrations).
The CO(2-1) line is our primary target. As no other accessible line (all systematically much fainter) is likely to be detected with any significant S/N, we position the other 3 ALMA basebands to try to detect and quantify any continuum. The ability to accurately subtract the continuum (when present) from the line is crucial, especially at low S/N. Continuum detections would also allow to quantify the amount of dust present in our targets in a spatially-resolved

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ubiquitely present at the centres of galaxies, supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are key to understand galaxy evolution. However, the SMBH mass-central velocity dispersion relation driving most theoretical efforts is based on a relatively small number of measurements and only a handful of methods. Our recent work has shown that it is straightforward to dynamically estimate the mass of SMBHs, by simply probing the near-Keplerian rotation of molecular disks around them at high angular resolution. In the ALMA era, this can yield hundreds of measurements in galaxies of all morphological types. As part of the mm-Wave Interferometric Survey of Dark Object Masses (WISDOM), we have already identified numerous promising targets, bright in CO and with regular nuclear dust distributions. In this proposal, we request moderate spatial resolution (0.5") CO(2-1) imaging of these targets, to weed out galaxies with perturbed (or absent) central molecular gas, and thus identify the best targets for follow-up SMBH mass measurements at high spatial resolution. We have 10 targets across the Hubble sequence, and all will lead to exciting ancillary science irrespective of future SMBH mass measurements.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00466.S, WISDOM: supermassive black hole mass measurements with molecular gas and ALMA, Kyoko Onishi 2015.1.00419.S, WISDOM: extending black hole demographics across the mass-size plane with ALMA, Timothy Davis
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00493.S, Weighing supermassive black holes with ALMA, Martin Bureau
